contentrichtext.text: "'''P'tit quinquin'''" is a song by [[Alexandre Desrousseaux]] which was written in the [[Picard language]] in 1853. Picard is closely related to [[French language|French]], and is spoken in two regions in the north of [[France]] – [[Nord-Pas-de-Calais]], [[Picardie]] and in parts of the [[Belgium|Belgian]] region of [[Wallonia]]. This simple [[lullaby]] (''P'tit quinquin'' means "little child") demonstrates the revival of Picard in the area, to the extent that it became the marching song of the northern soldiers leaving for the [[Franco-Prussian War]] of 1870. Today it could be called the unofficial anthem of the French city of [[Lille]], and more generally of the Nord-Pas-de-Calais region of France. {| cellpadding=5 align=center width=80% |The famous refrain (in Picard): |might be translated into French as: |--- |Dors, min p'tit quinquin,<br> Min p'tit pouchin, min gros rojin<br> Te m'fras du chagrin<br> Si te n'dors point ch'qu'à d'main. |''Dors, mon petit enfant,''<br> ''Mon petit poussin, mon gros raisin,''<br> ''Tu me feras du chagrin''<br> ''Si tu ne dors pas jusqu'à demain.'' |--- |And into English literally as: |  |--- |"Sleep, my little child,<br> My little chick, my plump grape,<br> You will cause me grief<br> If you don't sleep until tomorrow." |  |} ==See also== *[[Folk music]] ==External links== *[http://www.snh.be/lille/quinquin.htm Le P'tit quinquin] - Full lyrics in Picard (left), and a translation into French (right); also has a sound file of the chorus being sung in Picard (.wav and .ra formats) [[Category:1853 songs]]
